articles.title: Meeting Your Polish Partner's Family
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Meeting your Polish partner's family is a significant moment in your relationship. Polish families are typically close-knit, and making a good impression with their parents can mean the world to your partner. With the right phrases and cultural awareness, you'll win their hearts.

## The Essential First Greeting

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, bardzo mi mi≈Ço"
  translation="Good day, very nice to meet you"
  pronunciation="jen DOB-ry, BAR-dzo mee MEE-woh"
  context="The perfect formal greeting when meeting your partner's parents for the first time."
/>

## Formal Greetings

In Poland, formality matters, especially with your partner's parents. Always use the formal "Pan/Pani" (Mr./Mrs.) until they invite you to use first names.

<VocabCard
  word="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, Pani"
  translation="Good day, Ma'am"
  pronunciation="jen DOB-ry, PA-nee"
  example="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, Pani Kowalska. Bardzo mi mi≈Ço PaniƒÖ poznaƒá."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, Panie"
  translation="Good day, Sir"
  pronunciation="jen DOB-ry, PA-nyeh"
  example="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, Panie Kowalski. Jestem [your name]."
/>

<CultureTip title="The Pan/Pani System" flag="üáµüá±">
Polish uses "Pan" (Sir) and "Pani" (Ma'am) much more frequently than English. It's a sign of respect. With your partner's parents, always use this form until they explicitly offer "per ty" (the informal 'you'). This could take several meetings!
</CultureTip>

## Key Phrases for the First Meeting

<VocabCard
  word="Bardzo siƒô cieszƒô, ≈ºe mogƒô pa≈Ñstwa poznaƒá"
  translation="I'm very happy to meet you"
  pronunciation="BAR-dzo sheh CHEH-sheh, zheh MO-geh PAN-stva POZ-nach"
  example="Use this formal version when addressing both parents together."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Du≈ºo o pa≈Ñstwie s≈Çysza≈Çem/s≈Çysza≈Çam"
  translation="I've heard a lot about you (m/f speaker)"
  pronunciation="DOO-zho oh PAN-stvyeh swi-SHA-wem/swi-SHA-wam"
  example="Du≈ºo o pa≈Ñstwie s≈Çysza≈Çem - same dobre rzeczy!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Przynios≈Çem/Przynios≈Çam co≈õ dla pa≈Ñstwa"
  translation="I brought something for you (m/f speaker)"
  pronunciation="pshi-NYOS-wem/pshi-NYOS-wam tsosh dla PAN-stva"
  example="Say this when presenting your gift."
/>

## Gift-Giving Etiquette

In Poland, you never arrive empty-handed to someone's home!

### Appropriate Gifts

| Polish | English | Notes |
|--------|---------|-------|
| **Kwiaty** | Flowers | Always ODD numbers (3, 5, 7) - even is for funerals! |
| **Czekoladki** | Chocolates | Always appreciated |
| **Wino** | Wine | Choose good quality |
| **Ciasto** | Cake | Especially if homemade |
| **Co≈õ z mojego kraju** | Something from my country | Local specialties are valued |

<CultureTip title="Flower Rules" flag="üáµüá±">
IMPORTANT: Always bring an ODD number of flowers (3, 5, 7, 9...). Even numbers are reserved for funerals! Also avoid yellow flowers - they symbolize separation or infidelity. Red roses are romantic, so white or mixed bouquets are safer for parents.
</CultureTip>

## At the Dinner Table

Shared meals are central to Polish family life. Here are essential phrases:

<VocabCard
  word="Smacznego!"
  translation="Enjoy your meal! (Bon appetit)"
  pronunciation="smach-NEH-go"
  example="Wait for the host to say this before eating."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Pyszne! / Bardzo smaczne!"
  translation="Delicious! / Very tasty!"
  pronunciation="PISH-neh / BAR-dzo SMACH-neh"
  example="Pyszne! Dziƒôkujƒô za ten wspania≈Çy obiad."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Czy mogƒô prosiƒá o dok≈Çadkƒô?"
  translation="May I ask for seconds?"
  pronunciation="chi MO-geh PRO-sheech oh do-KWAD-keh"
  example="Asking for more is a great compliment to the cook!"
/>

<CultureTip title="Polish Hospitality" flag="üáµüá±">
Polish hosts will insist you eat more - this is normal and loving! "Nie, dziƒôkujƒô" (No, thank you) is often ignored. Expect at least 2-3 offers. It's part of the culture to ensure guests are well-fed. Accept graciously!
</CultureTip>

### Table Etiquette Tips

| Do This | Why |
|---------|-----|
| **Try everything** | Shows respect for their effort |
| **Compliment the food** | Polish hosts take pride in cooking |
| **Accept seconds** | Shows you're enjoying the meal |
| **Offer to help clear** | Appreciated but often declined |

## Family Vocabulary

| Polish | Pronunciation | English |
|--------|---------------|---------|
| **Mama** | MA-ma | Mom |
| **Tata** | TA-ta | Dad |
| **Babcia** | BAB-cha | Grandmother |
| **Dziadek** | JA-dek | Grandfather |
| **Brat** | brat | Brother |
| **Siostra** | SHYO-stra | Sister |
| **Ciocia** | CHO-cha | Aunt |
| **Wujek** | VOO-yek | Uncle |
| **Te≈õciowa** | tesh-CHO-va | Mother-in-law |
| **Te≈õƒá** | teshch | Father-in-law |

## Meeting Grandparents

Grandparents hold special status in Polish families. Address them respectfully:

<VocabCard
  word="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, Babciu!"
  translation="Good day, Grandma!"
  pronunciation="jen DOB-ry, BAB-choo"
  example="Dzie≈Ñ dobry, Babciu! Jak siƒô Babcia czuje?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Dziƒôkujƒô, Dziadku"
  translation="Thank you, Grandpa"
  pronunciation="jen-KOO-yeh, JA-dkoo"
  example="Dziƒôkujƒô bardzo, Dziadku, za te wspania≈Çe historie."
/>

## Talking About Yourself

<VocabCard
  word="Jestem z..."
  translation="I'm from..."
  pronunciation="YES-tem z..."
  example="Jestem z Ameryki / Anglii / Kanady."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Uczƒô siƒô polskiego"
  translation="I'm learning Polish"
  pronunciation="OO-cheh sheh pol-SKYE-go"
  example="Uczƒô siƒô polskiego, bo kocham pa≈Ñstwa c√≥rkƒô/syna."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Pracujƒô jako..."
  translation="I work as..."
  pronunciation="pra-TSOO-yeh YA-ko"
  example="Pracujƒô jako in≈ºynier / nauczyciel / programista."
/>

## Polite Responses

| Polish | English | When to Use |
|--------|---------|-------------|
| **Tak, proszƒô** | Yes, please | Accepting offers |
| **Bardzo chƒôtnie** | Very gladly | Enthusiastic agreement |
| **Dziƒôkujƒô, ale...** | Thank you, but... | Polite decline |
| **Z przyjemno≈õciƒÖ** | With pleasure | For invitations |

## Saying Goodbye

<VocabCard
  word="Dziƒôkujƒô za wspania≈Çy wiecz√≥r"
  translation="Thank you for a wonderful evening"
  pronunciation="jen-KOO-yeh za vspa-NYA-wi VYE-choor"
  example="Dziƒôkujƒô za wspania≈Çy wiecz√≥r i za pyszne jedzenie."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Mam nadziejƒô, ≈ºe jeszcze siƒô zobaczymy"
  translation="I hope we'll see each other again"
  pronunciation="mam na-JEH-yeh, zheh YESH-cheh sheh zo-BA-chi-mi"
  example="Express your desire for future meetings."
/>

## Things to Avoid

### Don't:
1. **Keep shoes on** - Ask if you should remove them (usually yes)
2. **Use "ty" too soon** - Wait for the formal invitation
3. **Decline gifts/food firmly** - Accept graciously
4. **Discuss politics** - Especially historical topics
5. **Arrive empty-handed** - Always bring a gift

### Do:
1. **Try speaking Polish** - Even with mistakes, they'll love it
2. **Show interest in Poland** - Ask questions about traditions
3. **Compliment sincerely** - The food, home, hospitality
4. **Share photos of your family** - It creates connection
5. **Offer to help** - With dishes, cleaning up

<CultureTip title="The Most Important Thing" flag="üáµüá±">
Polish families will adore you for trying to speak Polish - even imperfectly. Your effort shows respect for their culture and proves you're serious about their daughter or son. Don't be afraid to make mistakes!
</CultureTip>

## Sample Conversation

**You:** Dzie≈Ñ dobry! Bardzo mi mi≈Ço pa≈Ñstwa poznaƒá.
**Parents:** Dzie≈Ñ dobry! Wejd≈∫, wejd≈∫!
**You:** Przynios≈Çem kwiaty dla Pani.
**Mom:** Och, jakie piƒôkne! Dziƒôkujƒô!
**You:** Du≈ºo o pa≈Ñstwie s≈Çysza≈Çem od [partner's name].
**Dad:** Proszƒô, siadaj. Napij siƒô czego≈õ.
**You:** Dziƒôkujƒô. Bardzo chƒôtnie.

Good luck with your first family meeting! With respect, politeness, and a few Polish phrases, you'll make an excellent impression.

<CTA />

articles.title: Espanhol √© Dif√≠cil de Aprender? Guia Honesto para Casais
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Voc√™ est√° pensando em aprender espanhol para seu parceiro ou parceira? A boa not√≠cia √© que **espanhol √© uma das l√≠nguas mais f√°ceis para falantes de portugu√™s**! Com vocabul√°rio similar e estruturas familiares, voc√™ j√° tem um grande come√ßo. Mas ser√° que √© realmente t√£o simples quanto parece?

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Te amo"
  translation="Eu te amo"
  pronunciation="teh AH-moh"
  context="Express√£o universal de amor - igual em espanhol e portugu√™s!"
/>

## A Verdade Sobre a Dificuldade do Espanhol

**Espanhol √© considerado uma l√≠ngua Categoria I** pelo Foreign Service Institute dos EUA - a categoria mais f√°cil para falantes de ingl√™s. Para n√≥s brasileiros e portugueses, √© ainda mais simples!

**Tempo estimado para flu√™ncia b√°sica:** 3-6 meses com pr√°tica regular
**Tempo para conversa√ß√£o confort√°vel:** 6-12 meses
**Com um parceiro nativo:** Reduz pela metade! üöÄ

<CultureTip flag="üá™üá∏" title="Vantagem Ibero-americana">
O espanhol e o portugu√™s compartilham 89% de similaridade lexical! Isso significa que voc√™ j√° "sabe" quase 9 em cada 10 palavras. Aproveite essa vantagem √∫nica que poucos outros falantes t√™m.
</CultureTip>

## O Que Torna o Espanhol **Mais F√°cil**

### ‚úÖ Vantagens Que Voc√™ J√° Tem:

1. **Vocabul√°rio Familiar**
   Muitas palavras s√£o iguais ou muito parecidas:
   <VocabCard
     word="Familia"
     translation="Fam√≠lia"
     pronunciation="fah-MEE-lee-ah"
     example="La familia es muy importante."
   />

2. **Estrutura Gramatical Similar**
   A ordem das palavras √© praticamente id√™ntica ao portugu√™s

3. **Pron√∫ncia Previs√≠vel**
   O espanhol √© fon√©tico - se escreve como se fala!

4. ** verbos Regulares**
   96% dos verbos seguem padr√µes regulares (vs. 60% em portugu√™s)

5. **Seu Parceiro Nativo**
   Ter algu√©m para praticar diariamente acelera MUITO o aprendizado

## O Que Pode Ser **Desafiador**

### ‚ö†Ô∏è Cuidado Com Essas Armadilhas:

1. **Falsos Cognatos**
   Palavras que parecem iguais mas t√™m significados diferentes:
   - *"Embarazada"* n√£o significa "embara√ßada" - significa **gr√°vida**! üòÖ

2. **Pron√∫ncia da RR e J**
   O som da RR e J espanhola pode ser diferente do portugu√™s

3. **Tempos Verbais**
   O subjuntivo √© usado com mais frequ√™ncia que em portugu√™s
   [Aprenda mais sobre o modo subjuntivo aqui](/learn/pt/es/spanish-subjunctive-mood-explained/)

4. **"Ser" vs "Estar"**
   Duas formas de "ser" com usos diferentes do portugu√™s

5. **Varia√ß√µes Regionais**
   Espanhol da Espanha vs. Am√©rica Latina tem diferen√ßas importantes
   [Descubra as principais diferen√ßas aqui](/learn/pt/es/spain-vs-latin-american-spanish-differences/)

## Cronograma Realista para Casais

| N√≠vel | Tempo Estimado | Com Parceiro Nativo |
|-------|----------------|---------------------|
| **Frases B√°sicas** | 2-4 semanas | 1-2 semanas |
| **Conversas Simples** | 2-4 meses | 1-2 meses |
| **Falar com a Fam√≠lia** | 4-6 meses | 2-3 meses |
| **Fluente** | 1-2 anos | 8-12 meses |

<CultureTip flag="üá™üá∏" title="Imers√£o Rom√¢ntica">
Casais que praticam 15 minutos por dia juntos aprendem 3x mais r√°pido! Use momentos rom√¢nticos para praticar - "bom dia" na cama, "te amo" antes de dormir. Aprender junto fortalece o relacionamento!
</CultureTip>

## A Vantagem de Aprender Como Casal

**Por que aprender espanhol com seu parceiro √© mais f√°cil:**

1. **Motiva√ß√£o Natural**
   Voc√™ quer se comunicar com quem ama - n√£o tem motiva√ß√£o melhor!

2. **Pr√°tica Di√°ria Garantida**
   Cada conversa √© uma aula particular gr√°tis

3. **Contexto Emocional**
   Aprender durante momentos especiais fixa melhor a mem√≥ria

4. **Corre√ß√£o Amorosa**
   Seu parceiro corrige com carinho, sem julgamentos

5. **Cultura Compartilhada**
   Voc√™ aprende n√£o s√≥ a l√≠ngua, mas as tradi√ß√µes da fam√≠lia

<VocabCard
  word="Media naranja"
  translation="Minha cara metade (literal: metade da laranja)"
  pronunciation="MEH-dee-ah nah-RAHN-hah"
  example="Eres mi media naranja."
/>

## Dicas de Sucesso para Casais

### üí° Estrat√©gias Comprovadas:

1. **Comece Com Frases Rom√¢nticas**
   [Aprenda as frases mais importantes para casais aqui](/learn/pt/es/essential-spanish-phrases-for-couples/)

2. **Crie Rituais Di√°rios**
   "Buenos d√≠as, mi amor" toda manh√£

3. **Use Pet Names em Espanhol**
   [Descubra 50 nomes de carinho em espanhol](/learn/pt/es/spanish-pet-names-for-your-partner/)

4. **Assista S√©ries Juntos**
   Comece com dublagem em espanhol com legendas em portugu√™s

5. **Cante M√∫sicas Rom√¢nticas**
   Nada melhor que aprender com Juanes ou Shakira!

6. **Pratique Durante Tarefas**
   "Passa o sal" em espanhol na cozinha

7. **Comemore Cada Vit√≥ria**
   Cada nova palavra aprendida √© um motivo para comemorar!

## Por Onde Come√ßar Agora

### üìö Roteiro de Aprendizado Para Casais:

1. **Semana 1-2:** Sauda√ß√µes e [frases de carinho](/learn/pt/es/spanish-pet-names-for-your-partner/)
2. **Semana 3-4:** [Cumprimentos e despedidas](/learn/pt/es/spanish-greetings-and-farewells/)
3. **M√™s 2:** [Frases rom√¢nticas essenciais](/learn/pt/es/romantic-spanish-phrases-for-every-occasion/)
4. **M√™s 3:** [Como dizer "eu te amo" e expressar sentimentos](/learn/pt/es/how-to-say-i-love-you-in-spanish/)
5. **M√™s 4+:** Preparar-se para [conhecer a fam√≠lia](/learn/pt/es/meeting-your-spanish-partners-family/)

## A Conclus√£o: Voc√™ Consegue Sim!

**Espanhol √© uma das l√≠nguas mais f√°ceis para falantes de portugu√™s** - e com seu parceiro ao lado, fica ainda mais simples. Em apenas 3-6 meses, voc√™s estar√£o tendo conversas reais e criando mem√≥rias em um novo idioma.

O segredo √© come√ßar pequeno, ser consistente e manter o foco no amor que une voc√™s. Cada palavra aprendida √© um passo para se conectar ainda mais com seu parceiro e sua cultura.

**Pronto para come√ßar sua jornada de amor em espanhol?** Com nosso m√©todo desenvolvido especialmente para casais, voc√™ aprender√° as frases que realmente importam - as que tocam o cora√ß√£o.

<CTA />

sections: ## O Que Torna o Espanhol **Mais F√°cil**

articles.title: Small Talk p√• Russisk: Samtalestartere for Par
articles.content:
Small talk er kunsten at holde samtalen k√∏rende. N√•r du m√∏der din partners venner og familie, har du brug for russiske samtalestartere. Se ogs√• vores [russiske hilsner og farvel](/learn/da/ru/russian-greetings-and-farewells/).

<PhraseOfDay
  word="–ö–∞–∫ –¥–µ–ª–∞?"
  translation="Hvordan har du det?"
  pronunciation="kak dee-LAH?"
  context="En klassisk samtale√•bner"
/>

## Isbrydere

Start samtalen med selvtillid:

<VocabCard
  word="–ü—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ –ø–æ–∑–Ω–∞–∫–æ–º–∏—Ç—å—Å—è"
  translation="Rart at m√∏de dig"
  pronunciation="pree-YAHT-nah pahz-nah-KOH-meet-sya"
  example="–û—á–µ–Ω—å –ø—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ –ø–æ–∑–Ω–∞–∫–æ–º–∏—Ç—å—Å—è!"
  exampleTranslation="Det er s√• rart at m√∏de dig!"
/>

| Russisk | Dansk | Udtale |
|---------|-------|--------|
| **–ü—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ –ø–æ–∑–Ω–∞–∫–æ–º–∏—Ç—å—Å—è** | Rart at m√∏de dig | pree-YAHT-nah pahz-nah-KOH-meet-sya |
| **–Ø —Ç–∞–∫ –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ –≤–∞—Å —Å–ª—ã—à–∞–ª** | Jeg har h√∏rt s√• meget om dig | yah tak MNOH-gah oh vahs SLEE-shal |
| **–ö–∞–∫ –≤—ã –∑–Ω–∞–µ—Ç–µ [partner]?** | Hvordan kender du [partner]? | kahk vwee ZNAH-ee-tye? |
| **–í—ã –∑–¥–µ—Å—å –≤–ø–µ—Ä–≤—ã–µ?** | Er det f√∏rste gang du er her? | vwee zdyes vpyer-VWI-yeh? |
| **–ö–∞–∫–æ–µ –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–æ–µ –º–µ—Å—Ç–æ** | Sikke et dejligt sted | kah-KOH-yeh pryek-RAHS-nah-yeh MYE-stah |

<CultureTip flag="üá∑üá∫" title="Small talk kultur">
Russere v√¶rds√¶tter dybere samtaler end overfladisk small talk. V√¶r forberedt p√• at dele meninger og have rigtige diskussioner.
</CultureTip>

## Klassiske Emner

### Vejret
- **–ü—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–∞—è –ø–æ–≥–æ–¥–∞ —Å–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è** (Sikke dejligt vejr i dag) - "pryek-RAHS-nah-yah pah-GOH-dah see-VOHD-nyah"
- **–°–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è —Ö–æ–ª–æ–¥–Ω–æ** (Det er koldt i dag) - "see-VOHD-nyah KHOH-lahd-nah"
- **–ù–∞–¥–µ—é—Å—å, –ø–æ–≥–æ–¥–∞ –æ—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–µ–π** (H√•ber vejret holder) - "nah-DYEY-us, pah-GOH-dah ah-STAH-nyet-sya khah-ROH-shey"

### Weekendplaner
- **–ï—Å—Ç—å –ø–ª–∞–Ω—ã –Ω–∞ –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–Ω—ã–µ?** (Har du planer til weekenden?) - "yest plah-NWI nah vwi-khahd-NIH-yeh?"
- **–ß—Ç–æ –¥–µ–ª–∞–ª–∏ –Ω–∞ –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–Ω—ã—Ö?** (Hvad lavede du i weekenden?) - "shtoh DYEH-lah-lee nah vwi-khahd-NWIKH?"
- **–ú—ã —Å–æ–±–∏—Ä–∞–µ–º—Å—è...** (Vi skal til...) - "mwee sah-bee-RAH-yem-sya..."

### Ferier og Rejser
- **–í—ã –∫—É–¥–∞-–Ω–∏–±—É–¥—å –µ–∑–¥–∏–ª–∏?** (Har du rejst nogen steder?) - "vwee koo-DAH-nee-boot YEZ-dee-lee?"
- **–ì–¥–µ –≤—ã –æ—Ç–¥—ã—Ö–∞–ª–∏?** (Hvor var du p√• ferie?) - "gdye vwee aht-dwi-KHAH-lee?"
- **–Ø –±—ã —Ö–æ—Ç–µ–ª –ø–æ—Å–µ—Ç–∏—Ç—å...** (Jeg vil gerne bes√∏ge...) - "yah bwi khah-TYEL pah-sye-TEET..."

## Sp√∏rge til Interesser

<VocabCard
  word="–ß–µ–º –≤—ã –∑–∞–Ω–∏–º–∞–µ—Ç–µ—Å—å –≤ —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–Ω–æ–µ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è?"
  translation="Hvad laver du i fritiden?"
  pronunciation="chyem vwee zah-nee-MAH-ee-tyes fsva-BOHD-nah-yeh VRYEH-myah?"
  example="–ß–µ–º —Ç—ã –ª—é–±–∏—à—å –∑–∞–Ω–∏–º–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ —Å–≤–æ–±–æ–¥–Ω–æ–µ –≤—Ä–µ–º—è?"
  exampleTranslation="Hvad kan du lide at lave i din fritid?"
/>

- **–ß—Ç–æ –≤–∞–º –Ω—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—Å—è –¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å?** (Hvad kan du lide at lave?) - "shtoh vahm NRAH-veet-sya DYEH-laht?"
- **–í—ã —Å–ª–µ–¥–∏—Ç–µ –∑–∞ —Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç–æ–º?** (F√∏lger du sport?) - "vwee SLEH-dee-tye zah SPOHR-tahm?"
- **–ö–∞–∫—É—é –º—É–∑—ã–∫—É –≤—ã –ª—é–±–∏—Ç–µ?** (Hvilken musik kan du lide?) - "kah-KOO-yu MOO-zwi-koo vwee lyoo-BEE-tye?"
- **–°–º–æ—Ç—Ä–µ–ª–∏ –∫–∞–∫–∏–µ-–Ω–∏–±—É–¥—å —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–∏–µ —Ñ–∏–ª—å–º—ã?** (Har du set nogen gode film for nylig?) - "smah-TRYEH-lee kah-KEE-yeh-nee-boot khah-ROH-shwi-yeh feel-MWI?"

## Arbejde og Karriere

| Russisk | Dansk | Udtale |
|---------|-------|--------|
| **–ß–µ–º –≤—ã –∑–∞–Ω–∏–º–∞–µ—Ç–µ—Å—å?** | Hvad arbejder du med? | chyem vwee zah-nee-MAH-ee-tyes? |
| **–ö–∞–∫ –¥–∞–≤–Ω–æ –≤—ã —ç—Ç–∏–º –∑–∞–Ω–∏–º–∞–µ—Ç–µ—Å—å?** | Hvor l√¶nge har du gjort det? | kahk dahv-NOH vwee EH-teem zah-nee-MAH-ee-tyes? |
| **–í–∞–º –Ω—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—Å—è?** | Kan du lide det? | vahm NRAH-veet-sya? |
| **–ó–≤—É—á–∏—Ç –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–æ** | Det lyder interessant | ZVOO-cheet een-tye-RYES-nah |
| **–ù–∞–≤–µ—Ä–Ω–æ–µ, –≤—ã –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –∑–∞–Ω—è—Ç—ã** | Du m√• v√¶re travl | nah-VYER-nah-yeh, vwee OH-chyen ZAH-nyah-twi |

<CultureTip flag="üá∑üá∫" title="Emner at undg√•">
Russere er mere √•bne over for at diskutere politik end mange vesterl√¶ndinge, men hold samtalen let ved f√∏rste m√∏de. Undg√• at kritisere Rusland.
</CultureTip>

## Holde Samtalen K√∏rende

<VocabCard
  word="–†–∞—Å—Å–∫–∞–∂–∏—Ç–µ –ø–æ–¥—Ä–æ–±–Ω–µ–µ"
  translation="Fort√¶l mere"
  pronunciation="rahs-kah-ZHEE-tye pahd-ROHB-nyeh-yeh"
  example="–†–∞—Å—Å–∫–∞–∂–∏—Ç–µ –º–Ω–µ –æ–± —ç—Ç–æ–º –ø–æ–¥—Ä–æ–±–Ω–µ–µ!"
  exampleTranslation="Fort√¶l mig mere om det!"
/>

- **–ü—Ä–∞–≤–¥–∞?** (Virkelig?) - "PRAHV-dah?"
- **–ó–∞–º–µ—á–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ** (Det er fantastisk) - "zah-mye-CHAH-tyel-nah"
- **–°–æ–≥–ª–∞—Å–µ–Ω** (Jeg er enig) - "sah-GLAH-syen"
- **–ü–æ–Ω—è—Ç–Ω–æ** (Jeg forst√•r) - "pah-NYAHT-nah"

## Reagere og Nikke Med

| Russisk | Dansk | Brug |
|---------|-------|------|
| **–û–≥–æ** | Wow | Overraskelse |
| **–ö—Ä—É—Ç–æ** | Fedt | Positiv |
| **–ü–æ–Ω—è—Ç–Ω–æ** | Jeg forst√•r | Forst√•else |
| **–¢–æ—á–Ω–æ** | Ja, lige pr√¶cis | Enighed |

## Mad og Drikke

- **–ï–¥–∞ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –≤–∫—É—Å–Ω–∞—è** (Maden er l√¶kker) - "yeh-DAH OH-chyen FKOOS-nah-yah"
- **–ù–µ —Ö–æ—Ç–∏—Ç–µ —á—Ç–æ-–Ω–∏–±—É–¥—å –≤—ã–ø–∏—Ç—å?** (Vil du have noget at drikke?) - "nyeh khah-TEE-tye shtoh-nee-boot VWIH-peet?"
- **–ß—Ç–æ –≤—ã –ª—é–±–∏—Ç–µ –µ—Å—Ç—å?** (Hvad kan du lide at spise?) - "shtoh vwee lyoo-BEE-tye yest?"

## Skifte Emne

- **–ö—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–∏...** (Forresten...) - "KSTAH-tee..."
- **–ö—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–∏ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä—è...** (Apropos...) - "KSTAH-tee gah-vah-RYAH..."
- **–ö—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–∏, –æ –¥—Ä—É–≥–æ–º...** (Noget helt andet...) - "KSTAH-tee, oh droo-GOHM..."

## Afslutte Samtalen

<VocabCard
  word="–ë—ã–ª–æ –ø—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ –ø–æ–æ–±—â–∞—Ç—å—Å—è"
  translation="Det var hyggeligt at snakke"
  pronunciation="BWIH-lah pree-YAHT-nah pah-ahb-SHAHT-sya"
  example="–ë—ã–ª–æ —Ç–∞–∫ –ø—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ –ø–æ–æ–±—â–∞—Ç—å—Å—è —Å –≤–∞–º–∏!"
  exampleTranslation="Det var s√• hyggeligt at snakke med dig!"
/>

- **–ë–æ—é—Å—å, –º–Ω–µ –ø–æ—Ä–∞ –∏–¥—Ç–∏** (Jeg m√• desv√¶rre g√•) - "bah-YOOS, mnyeh pah-RAH eet-TEE"
- **–ù–∞–¥–µ—é—Å—å, –º—ã –µ—â–µ —É–≤–∏–¥–∏–º—Å—è** (Jeg h√•ber vi ses igen) - "nah-DYEY-us, mwee yeh-SHOH oo-VEE-deem-sya"
- **–ú–Ω–µ –ø–æ–Ω—Ä–∞–≤–∏–ª—Å—è –Ω–∞—à —Ä–∞–∑–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä** (Jeg har nydt samtalen) - "mnyeh pah-NRAH-veel-sya nahsh rahz-gah-VOHR"

## Tips til Russisk Small Talk

1. **Smil og lyt** - 70% lytning, 30% tale
2. **Stil √•bne sp√∏rgsm√•l** - Mere end ja/nej
3. **Find f√¶lles interesser** - Byg videre p√• dem
4. **Accepter pauser** - De er naturlige
5. **√òv dig** - Det bliver nemmere med tiden

For flere fraser, tjek [russiske fraser for par](/learn/da/ru/russian-essential-phrases-for-couples/).

articles.title: ≈†panƒõlsk√© fr√°ze pro setk√°n√≠ s rodiƒçi partnera
articles.content:
Ve ≈°panƒõlsk√© kultu≈ôe je rodina nesm√≠rnƒõ d≈Øle≈æit√°. Tyto fr√°ze v√°m pomohou udƒõlat skvƒõl√Ω dojem na rodiƒçe partnera.

## Prvn√≠ setk√°n√≠

### "Mucho gusto en conocerles."
**P≈ôeklad:** Je mi potƒõ≈°en√≠m v√°s poznat.

---

### "[Partner] me ha hablado mucho de ustedes."
**P≈ôeklad:** [Partner] mi o v√°s hodnƒõ vypr√°vƒõl/a.

---

### "Muchas gracias por invitarme."
**P≈ôeklad:** Mockr√°t dƒõkuji za pozv√°n√≠.

---

### "Tienen una casa muy bonita."
**P≈ôeklad:** M√°te velmi kr√°sn√Ω d≈Øm.

---

## U j√≠dla

### "Est√° delicioso! Me podr√≠a dar la receta?"
**P≈ôeklad:** Je to vynikaj√≠c√≠! Mohla bych dostat recept?

---

### "Todo se ve maravilloso."
**P≈ôeklad:** V≈°echno vypad√° skvƒõle.

---

### "Me encantar√≠a aprender a preparar esto."
**P≈ôeklad:** R√°da bych se nauƒçil/a toto p≈ôipravit.

---

## Projeven√≠ z√°jmu

### "Me encantar√≠a ver fotos de [partner] de peque√±o/a."
**P≈ôeklad:** R√°da bych vidƒõl/a fotky [partnera] z dƒõtstv√≠.

---

### "C√≥mo se conocieron ustedes?"
**P≈ôeklad:** Jak jste se poznali?

---

### "Qu√© les gusta hacer en su tiempo libre?"
**P≈ôeklad:** Co r√°di dƒõl√°te ve voln√©m ƒçase?

---

## Nab√≠dka pomoci

### "Puedo ayudar en algo?"
**P≈ôeklad:** Mohu s nƒõƒç√≠m pomoci?

---

### "Por favor, d√©jeme ayudar con los platos."
**P≈ôeklad:** Pros√≠m, dovolte mi pomoci s n√°dob√≠m.

---

## Rozlouƒçen√≠

### "Gracias por una velada maravillosa."
**P≈ôeklad:** Dƒõkuji za n√°dhern√Ω veƒçer.

---

### "Espero verles pronto otra vez."
**P≈ôeklad:** Douf√°m, ≈æe se brzy zase uvid√≠me.

---

## Kulturn√≠ tipy

**Rodina je z√°klad:** Ve ≈°panƒõlsk√© kultu≈ôe je rodina na prvn√≠m m√≠stƒõ.

**Vyk√°n√≠:** Pou≈æ√≠vejte "usted/ustedes" s rodiƒçi partnera, dokud v√°m nenab√≠dnou tyk√°n√≠.

**J√≠dlo:** Obƒõdov√© setk√°n√≠ m≈Ø≈æe trvat hodiny - buƒète trpƒõliv√≠.

**D√°rek:** P≈ôineste v√≠no, dezert nebo kvƒõtiny.

S tƒõmito fr√°zemi udƒõl√°te skvƒõl√Ω dojem na ≈°panƒõlskou rodinu.
